material.mattext: Which of the following tables represents the probability distribution of X?

Incorrect. While it is true that the possible values that X can take are 0,1,2,3 and 4, the corresponding probabilities are wrong. In order to find the probability that X takes the certain value, you need to plug in this value into the formula. So for example, P(X=1)= (1+2)(5-1)/50=12/50.

Incorrect. While it is true that the possible values that X can take are 0,1,2,3 and 4, the corresponding probabilities are wrong. Note also that your selection is not a legitimate probability distribution since the sum of the probabilities of all possible values is NOT 1 as it should be. In order to find the probability that X takes the certain value, you need to plug in this value into the formula. So for example, P(X=1)= (1+2)(5-1)/50=12/50.

Incorrect. Note that X takes the values 0,1,2,3,4 and not, as your selection suggests, 1,2,3,4,5. In order to find the probability that X takes the certain value, you need to plug in this value into the formula. So for example, P(X=1)= (1+2)(5-1)/50=12/50.

Good Job! This is the right probability distribution. As you probably did, in order to find the probability that X takes the certain value, you need to plug in this value into the formula. So for example, P(X=1)= (1+2)(5-1)/50=12/50. Note that this is a legitimate probability distribution since all the probabilities are between 0 and 1, and their sum is 1
